children.subject:
With all of the math courses you’ve taken, I don’t think that you need any other preparation for CS 189.  I’m currently in 170 and 189, and I feel like I’m doing fine even though I’ve only taken 16A, 54, 61A/B/C, and 70 (no 16B, 53, 110, 126, or 127).

That being said, I agree with Sahai’s general belief that you will get a lot more out of the class if you’ve taken 126 and 127 (mostly 127 probably) because you will be able to focus more on the big picture and main idea rather than the nitty gritty math of the proofs.

history.content:
I am double majoring in Applied math and CS. I took most of math courses(Math 104, 110, 113, 185) and few CS courses(61A,B and currently taking 61C, 168 and 188). Although I didn't take CS 70, I took Math 55. I am planning to take CS 170 (and Math 128A) next semester and kinda afraid to take CS189 with it because I heard these two are most heavy-workloads courses in CS department. So I searched a bit and found that both EE 126 and EE 127 are great courses to prepare for CS 189. I saw on one post that Prof. Sahai suggests that with experiences with EE 16A/B take 126 and without them take 127(fyi, I havn't take either 16A or 16B). How these two courses are different? Or is there any course in math department that are particularly helpful for CS 189? I also heard that EE 126 also has heavy workload, so is it just better to take 127 in term of balancing workload throughout the semester?

Any suggestion would be great!
history.subject: Course recommendation to prepare CS189?
